question_text.markdown:
Number of elements from the following that CANNOT form compounds with valencies which match with their respective group valencies is ____.

B, C, N, S, O, F, P, Al, Si

(JEE Main, 04 Apr 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: 2**

F (Group 17) and O (Group 16) cannot expand their octet (no d-orbitals in Period 2) and cannot show group valency of 7 and 6 respectively. All others (B, C, N, S, P, Al, Si) can show their group valency.

question_text.markdown:
The correct order of first ionization enthalpy values of the following elements is:

(A) O, (B) N, (C) Be, (D) F, (E) B

(JEE Main, 04 Apr 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) E < C < A < B < D i.e. B < Be < O < N < F**

IE1 (kJ/mol): B(800) < Be(899) < O(1314) < N(1402) < F(1681). Anomalies: Be > B (stable 2s2); N > O (stable half-filled 2p3).

question_text.markdown:
The statement(s) that are correct about the species O2-, F-, Na+ and Mg2+:

(A) All are isoelectronic
(B) All have the same nuclear charge
(C) O2- has the largest ionic radii
(D) Mg2+ has the smallest ionic radii

(JEE Main, 05 Apr 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) A, C and D only**

A: All have 10 electrons -> isoelectronic. Correct. B: Nuclear charges differ (O=8, F=9, Na=11, Mg=12). Wrong. C: O2-(Z=8) lowest Z -> largest. Correct. D: Mg2+(Z=12) highest Z -> smallest. Correct.

question_text.markdown:
Given below are two statements:

**Statement I:** In group 13, the stability of +1 oxidation state increases down the group.

**Statement II:** The atomic size of gallium is greater than that of aluminium.

(JEE Main, 05 Apr 2024)

options.text: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4)**

St. I: Inert pair effect increases down Group 13 -> +1 OS stability: Tl > In > Ga > Al. Correct.
St. II: Ga(135 pm) < Al(143 pm) due to poor 3d shielding (d-block contraction). Ga is SMALLER than Al. Incorrect.

question_text.markdown:
The electron affinity values are negative for:

A. Be->Be-, B. N->N-, C. O->O2-, D. Na->Na-, E. Al->Al-

(JEE Main, 06 Apr 2024)

options.text: A, B, D and E only

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) A, B and C only**

Negative EA = endothermic (energy required). A(Be): filled 2s2 resists extra electron. B(N): half-filled 2p3 extra stability. C(O->O2-): second electron addition always endothermic. D(Na) and E(Al) have positive EA (exothermic, readily gain electrons).

question_text.markdown:
Given below are two statements:

**Statement I:** The oxidation state of an element in a compound is the charge acquired by its atom on the basis of electron gain enthalpy consideration from other atoms.

**Statement II:** p-pi-p-pi bond formation is more prevalent in second period elements over other periods.

(JEE Main, 09 Apr 2024)

options.text: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3)**

St. I INCORRECT: Oxidation state is based on electronegativity, not electron gain enthalpy.
St. II CORRECT: Second period elements (C, N, O) form strong p-pi-p-pi bonds due to small size allowing good lateral overlap.

question_text.markdown:
**Assertion A:** The first ionisation enthalpy decreases across a period.

**Reason R:** The increasing nuclear charge outweighs the shielding across the period.

(JEE Main, 29 Jan 2024)

options.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) A false, R true**

A is FALSE: IE1 generally INCREASES across a period. R is TRUE: Increasing nuclear charge outweighs shielding, which is WHY IE increases (not decreases) across a period.

question_text.markdown:
The correct sequence of electron gain enthalpy of the elements listed below is:

A. Ar, B. Br, C. F, D. S

(JEE Main, 31 Jan 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) A > D > B > C (least negative to most negative)**

EGE: Ar(+35, endothermic) > S(-200) > Br(-325) > F(-328) kJ/mol. Ar has positive EGE (noble gas, stable). F has more negative EGE than Br anomalously... wait: Cl(-349) > F(-328) > Br(-325). So Ar > S > Br > F in terms of least negative to most negative.

question_text.markdown:
Consider elements A', B', C', D' where A' and B' are in Period 2, C' and D' in Period 3; A' and C' in Group 1, B' and D' in Group 2. Which of the following is/are true?

A. Order of atomic radii: B' < A' < D' < C'
B. Order of metallic character: B' < A' < D' < C'
C. Size: D' < C' < B' < A'
D. Order of ionic radii: B'+ < A'+ < D'+ < C'+

(JEE Main, 31 Jan 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) A, B and D only**

A'=Li, B'=Be, C'=Na, D'=Mg. A: Be < Li < Mg < Na in atomic radii. Correct. B: Be < Li < Mg < Na in metallic character. Correct. C: D'(Mg) < C'(Na) is wrong since Na > Mg. Incorrect. D: Be2+(45) < Li+(76) < Mg2+(72) < Na+(102). Correct.

question_text.markdown:
Given below are two statements:

**Statement I:** Both metal and non-metal exist in p and d-block elements.

**Statement II:** Non-metals have higher ionisation enthalpy and higher electronegativity than the metals.

(JEE Main, 01 Feb 2024)

options.text: Both Statement I and Statement II are false
Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Statement I is true but Statement II is false
Both Statement I and Statement II are true

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Both true**

St. I: p-block has metals (Pb, Sn, Bi), non-metals (C, N, O, F) and metalloids. d-block has only metals. The statement is broadly accepted as true for p-block. St. II: Non-metals have higher IE and EN than metals. Correct.

question_text.markdown:
Which one of the following elements will remain as liquid inside pure boiling water?

(JEE Main, 06 Apr 2023)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) Ga**

Boiling water = 100 C. Ga melts at 29.76 C and boils at 2204 C, so it remains liquid in boiling water without reacting. Br2 boils at 59 C (evaporates). Li melts at 180.5 C (still solid). Cs melts at 28.5 C but reacts violently with water.

question_text.markdown:
Group-13 elements react with O2 to form oxides of type M2O3. Which among the following is the most basic oxide?

(JEE Main, 06 Apr 2023)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) Tl2O3**

Metallic character increases down Group 13: B < Al < Ga < In < Tl. More metallic = more basic oxide. Tl is most metallic in Group 13, so Tl2O3 is most basic. B2O3 is acidic.

question_text.markdown:
The correct order of electronegativity for given elements is:

(JEE Main, 08 Apr 2023)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) Br > C > At > P**

Electronegativity (Pauling): Br(2.96) > C(2.55) > At(2.2) > P(2.19). Br is in Group 17 Period 4, highly electronegative. At is large so less electronegative than C.

question_text.markdown:
The correct order of metallic character is:

(JEE Main, 10 Apr 2023)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) K > Ca > Be**

Metallic character increases down a group and decreases across a period. K (Group 1, Period 4) > Ca (Group 2, Period 4) > Be (Group 2, Period 2). K has lowest IE and is most metallic.

question_text.markdown:
Identify the correct order of standard enthalpy of formation of sodium halides.

(JEE Main, 13 Apr 2023)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) NaI < NaBr < NaCl < NaF**

Standard enthalpy of formation (kJ/mol): NaF(-576) < NaCl(-411) < NaBr(-361) < NaI(-288). NaF is most exothermic. Order from least to most negative: NaI < NaBr < NaCl < NaF.

question_text.markdown:
Given below are two statements:

**Statement I:** The decrease in first ionization enthalpy from B to Al is much larger than that from Al to Ga.

**Statement II:** The d orbitals in Ga are completely filled.

(JEE Main, 29 Jan 2023)

options.text: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct.
Both the statements I and II are correct
Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
Both the statements I and II are incorrect

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) Both correct**

St. I: IE1: B=800, Al=577, Ga=579 kJ/mol. Drop B->Al = 223 kJ/mol. Drop Al->Ga = only 2 kJ/mol. Correct.
St. II: Ga config [Ar] 3d10 4s2 4p1. 3d orbitals are completely filled. Correct. This poor 3d shielding causes Ga's IE to be close to Al's.
